did.unittitle: Edvard Bech Collection

repository.corpname: Marist College Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: This collection depicts the live of Edvard Bech, who born in Denmark in 1812 moved to New York in 1838 where he formed a trading firm that he would run for forty seven years. In 1863 he purchased a sixty-five acre farm along the Hudson River which he named “Rosenlund” and hired Danish architect Detlef Lineau to design the estate. This collection contains papers concerning the Bech famil history and businesses, materials compiled by Viggo Bech Rambusch for his monograph, and materials pretaining to the Roselunf estate.
did.physloc: Please contact the Marist College Archives and Special Collections for information regarding use and access of this collection.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: This collection contains letters, photos, documents, manuscripts, records and newspaper clippings concerning the Bech family history and businesses in the United States. It was compiled by Viggo Bech Rambusch through his creation of a monograph on the Bech family and life in Duchess County. This collection also contains material on Danish architect Lineau Detlef and his plans for the Rosenlund estate as well as a Daguerreotype of Edvard Bech’s estate.

acqinfo.p: Viggo Bech Rambusch donated his records concerning the history of Edvard Bech and Rosenlund to Marist College.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Edvard Bech was born May 4th, 1812 in Denmark. He was educated at the University of Copenhagen and his father Jorgen Bech was a prominent merchant. Bech emigrated to New York in 1838 where in 1842 he formed a trading firm which would run for forty seven years. After the death of his father Jorgen Peter Bech in 1848 he was left a large inheritance which he used to invest in the Tuckerman iron trade company which was then renamed Tuckerman and Bech. Bech became the Danish Consulate in New York from 1842 until 1858. He married Elizabeth Hossack in 1846 and moved to Poughkeepsie in 1851 where he lived for about ten years. During the Civil War Bech became very wealthy due to his business in the iron works.

In 1863 he purchased a sixty-five acre farm along the Hudson River which he named “Rosenlund” and hired Danish architect Detlef Lineau to design the estate. Construction was started and completed on a carriage house, a gate house, and a gardner’s cottage. Plans for a main house were created but not built due to Bech’s death in 1873. Lineau was commissioned to build the Bech Family Mausoleum in the Poughkeepsie cemetery for Edvard. His son, George Bech, continued to run Bech’s businesses until his own death in 1890. The order of the Marist Brother’s bought the estate in 1908. The three buildings designed by Lineau, now called Greystone, St. Peters and Kieran Gatehouse continue to be maintained by Marist College and gained historical recognition in 1991.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions to Access
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection

For more information please visit the following website: http://www.loc.gov/copyright/title17/.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: These records are organized into five series: 1) The Bech Family, has five subseries, 2) Edvard Bech, Ironmaster, has four subseries, 3) Danish Consul, has one subseries, 4) Rosenlund, has five subseries, 5) The Edvard Bech Monograph, has two subseries.
Series are arranged by subject, chronologically, or by type.

did.unittitle: 1. The Bech Family

scopecontent.p: Series contains portraits and pictures of the Bech family, history of the family, obituaries and death notices, materials about the familiy masoleum, and materials on the Linden Museum.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1.1: Portraits and Pictures of the Bech Family
Pictures of Edvard Bech’s grandfather, Jørgen Peter Bech (1743-1812) and Edvard Bech’s father, Jorgen Peter Bech (1782-1846). (Taped onto a sheet of paper)
Black and white portrait of Jorgen Peter Bech
Pictures of Edvard Bech’s home in Denmark (taken from a painting), a Lego model of Edvard Bech’s home in Denmark, and a photograph of Edvard Bech’s home in Denmark. (Taped onto a sheet of paper)
Three color photos of the exterior Edvard’s home in Denmark with the Black Rooster Symbol found on Jorgen Bech’s ships Photograph of the Black Rooster, the symbol on Jørgen Peter Bech’s ships.
Copy of a portrait of Edvard Bech.
Black and white photo of Edvard Bech.
Sepia photo of Edvard Bech.
Photocopy enlargement of Edvard Bech photo.
Copy of a portrait of Elizabeth McCarty Hossack Bech, the wife of Edvard Bech.
Portrait of Elizabeth Hossack Bech from the Royal Library in Copenhagen.
Copy of a family photograph.
Photocopy of photo of Edvard Bech and Family found in Duchess County Historical Society Year Book, Volume 76.
Photocopy of photo of Mrs. Henri Braem.
Portrait of George Bech, Danish Consul.
Picture of Carl Adolph Rothe Bech.
Folder of extra copies of Bech family home and negatives.

Notes on Edvard Bech’s life with an attached letter to Viggo Rambusch from Edward J.A. Bech, sending these notes.
Information on Bech Family Service in the Danish Consulate.
Photocopied information on many Bech family members from Patriciske Slægter by Anden Samling.

Dutchess County Historical Society Year Book 1991- Volume 76, which includes the monograph on Edvard Bech entitled ‘Edvard Bech, Citizen of Poughkeepsie 1851-1873’ by Viggo Bech Rambusch with Walter Averill on pages 49-56. (Additional photocopies of the article are also included)
Handwritten notes on Edvard Bech’s emigration and children by Viggo Rambusch.
Information on Edvard Bech as a student from the Copenhagen University Archives.
Handwritten information concerning Edvard Bech’s children by Viggo Rambusch.
Outline of Edvard Bech’s family, along with a family tree.
Copy of a Bech family tree.
Edvard Bech’s Family tree complied by Viggo Rambusch
Handwritten Notes on Elizabeth McCarty Hossack Bech and children by Viggo Rambusch.
Photocopy of article in Dutch entitled “Waldbygaard.”containing Bech family history, specifically Carl Bech.
Photocopy of a timeline of Edvard Bech’s life from the Henry Booth scrapbook.
Handwritten notes on Edvard Bech’s career in the Iron industry by Viggo Rambusch.
Hand drawn diagram of location of Bech’s companies in reference to the Hudson River.
Copy of Census from 1880 with Edvard Bech’s name listed
Copy of the New York Times announcement of George A. Bech’s marriage to Julia May entitled “Wedding in Baltimore.”
Letter to Eric Tillisch from Viggo B. Rambusch concerning Sophie Bech-Oxholm and the shooting competition she held each year.
Copy of the minutes of the Meeting of the Board of Directors in Stockbridge, Massachusetts- with Elisabeth Bech’s signature.
Notes on the Records of Christ Church 1911 about the specific Bech family monetary and volunteer contributions.
Photocopy of “A Summary of the History of the Church of the Holy Comforter” in Poughkeepsie NY with highlighted information on Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bech and their specific contributions to the church.
Letter in Danish from August and Elisabeth Bech to Viggo B. Rambusch giving information on the Bech family.
Subseries 1.3: Obituaries and Death Notices
Copies of Edvard Bech’s obituaries.

Correspondence between Mary Lou Davison and Viggo B. Rambusch concerning Edvard Bech’s obituary.

Correspondence between Viggo B. Rambusch and Dr. Ferdinand Opil concerning the obituary of Henri M. Braem (died in Vienna February 13, 1900) from 2002, translated from German to English. Attached is a copy of a German newspaper from February 14, 1900 with a translation of the death notice.
Copy of the article entitled “Kammerherreinde Oxholms Slægt,” both in Dutch and translated into English, about Sophie Oxholm’s death.

2. Edvard Bech, Ironmaster

scopecontent.p: Series contains materials pretaining to the painting of the ironworks, history and information on the iron industry, Forest of the Dean Iron ore company records, and information on the New York Canals.

4. Rosenlund

scopecontent.p: Series contains Materials related to Rosenlund, including photos, history, materials on Detlef Lienau, the National Register of Historic Sites, andHenri bream.
